Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Metabolic Network in Salmonella and its Response to Perturbations

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental question in biology is how metabolic pathways are integrated to result in the robust and efficient physiology characteristic of living cells. Current efforts to understand physiology as a complex system are comprised of modeling and reconstructing metabolic networks, and predicting their robustness from genomic sequences. Fundamental knowledge of biochemistry and metabolism, gained over several decades, provides the basis on which these global approaches are built. The proposed research focuses on integrating quantitative analysis into the study of a metabolism. Toward this end, investigators with diverse expertise will work together to quantify the metabolites of the system to assess the effect of specific perturbations; generate mathematical models from the metabolomic data; and iteratively test these models using genetic and biochemical approaches. This collaborative effort is anticipated to generate novel insights into the complexity and dynamics of integrated metabolic networks.

The proposed work is a collaboration between a microbial physiologist, a systems biologist with expertise in modeling and predicting metabolic networks, and a synthetic chemist with expertise in metabolomics. The team will utilize state-of-the-art techniques to define the integrated metabolic network of purine, histidine, and thiamine biosynthesis of Salmonella. A key focus is on a strain that lacks the purH gene, which results in the accumulation of the aminoimidazole carboxamide ribotide intermediate metabolite. This mutation reveals the unpredicted metabolic connections between the purine, histidine and thiamine metabolic networks. The accumulation of this metabolite in other organisms, including mammalian systems, is the basis for a number of severe hereditary disorders. The project will train students and postdoctoral fellows at the intersection of biology, mathematics, chemistry and computation, and hence, will lead to a highly skilled next-generation workforce. The investigators have a track record of training minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental feature of a living system is the complex network of biochemical pathways, collectively termed metabolism, that allow the organism to adapt and respond to different situations and environments. A central question in biology is how the components of metabolism work together to accomplish the capabilities we associate with living cells and organisms. Historically these questions have been addressed by investigators in distinct disciplines, each of which had its own unique strengths, but also limitations.  This proposal was initiated to address basic questions about the metabolism of a living cell by combining three powerful and complementary approaches. We accomplished the required synergism by bringing together three established investigators with distinct expertise in computational, experimental and technical approaches to biology. Specifically, we initiated a study that was meant to confirm the ability to integrate these approaches toward a better understanding of metabolism, and chose to work with a bacterial system. Microbes (e.g., bacteria) are the simplest organisms to study and have the broadest number of tools available for this work. Importantly, metabolic strategies are frequently conserved across biology, and so our results can often be extrapolated to define general biological paradigms. Our work provided a case study for the integration of modern technological tools and classical experimental tools. We found that, collectively, these tools could provide scientific insights not generated by a single approach, but significant troubleshooting was required. During the course of this project we identified problems, modified our approach to solve them and at the end were able to generate a revised plan that will take advantage of our team of experts to move forward. This plan became the core of a successful NSF application. The long term goal of this work is to generate a map of the regulated pathway flow through metabolism, much like a traffic map that responds to traffic jams. A significant outcome of this project was the training of young scientists. Each of the personnel involved in this project was exposed to and trained in interdisciplinary science. This training is increasingly critical in the future since interdisciplinary science requires continual innovation by unforeseeable combinations of the various technical and computational sectors of society.
